answers.answer: Sounds a lot like peripheral neuropathy to me.  Mine was mild because of a wrecked-up spine from a car wreck, and then it got worse when I got chemo-induced neuropathy on top of it.  Bad peripheral neuropathy will make it hard to grasp things with your hands, hard to walk normally, the fingers and toes hurt.  But since the EMG said you are getting "power" to your extremities, then as a layperson, it's hard for me to know what might have happened to cause this problem with the nerves going into your arms and legs.  I just don't know enough about things like diabetes, which can cause something similar to this.  Whomever you saw for this, I do not think they are good enough, because otherwise they would have decided what might be wrong and continued to test you or at least referred you to another specialist.  So, go to another dotor.

question: Hi all.  Having trouble chatting these days but have a question to ask.  Anyone have trouble with weakness in hands/lower legs that results in trouble letting go of things or raising fingers when typing?  My left hand is worse, and had trouble all day yesterday handing things to people and paying at register.  Legs are simply more diff to raise and walk (not new).  EMG's show no muscle/nerve damage as recently as Feb or March.  I've also broken same toe twice since Oct 2011 and possibly another, more recently, and cracked three toe nails... sounds worse than it feels b/c at times I don't feel much.  Spine is also ok.Thanks,Liz
title: Hands (especially left) slow reaction/release
